Availability bias occurs when a clinician relies on easily available information or an easily remembered diagnosis to the exclusion of less common diagnoses. In this case, the physician's recent experience with patients with the common cold led to an assumption of viral upper respiratory tract infection, causing the physician to overlook the possibility of gastroesophageal reflux disease. Confirmation bias occurs when a clinician seeks evidence to support an initial diagnosis rather than considering alternative possibilities. Anchoring bias occurs when a clinician becomes fixed on initial impressions or data, failing to adjust their thinking as more data becomes available. Framing bias occurs when the way information is presented or framed affects decision-making.  None of these biases accurately describe the cognitive bias in this scenario.
